Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

This was an excellent coming together of ingredients here: chicken, yogurt sauce of some sort, tangerines, clover, onions, and cheese. While I think the menu could be mixed up just a bit more with bowls and other offerings and the like, these sandwiches alone are enough to carry Souvla into franchise or multi-location greatness. Star Granted.  

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

With a slightly more varied menu this is an easy yes, but even with the existing offerings I'll highly recommend Souvla to anyone who will listen. Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: This place can be quite crowded like most places at peak dinner time. One has to queue up to order and then find a seat. I ordered some fries, some salad and a greek beer. The portion size for salad was really good.  The greek beer was quite interesting. Not being a yogurt lover personally, my options were somewhat limited. They did subtract the yogurt in my salad upon request.
author: Tejashree M.

description: Would best describe this as the perfect fast-casual dining. Fresh take on Mediterranean
author: Saadhya S.

description:
Very good Greek food. Quick and friendly service. 
Recommended - pork shoulder sandwich, lamb salad, fries, yogurt
author: D Z.

description: This place was soooo delicious!!! I enjoyed every morsel of each thing that we ordered. The lemon soup is absolutely velvety cooked to perfection.
author: Rimma A.

description:
Read a lot about this place so came here on a Sunday afternoon. The line extended put the door but moved very fast so don't let that deter you. 

Had a lamb pita wrap and a chicken salad. While the salad was good, I think the pita on the sandwich was too thick for a place ranked this high, so knocking a star off.
author: Vikas A.

description:
I dream of the veggie salad. 

Yep, it's that good! A big ol' bowl of kale, pea sprouts, walnuts, olives, pickled red onion, and sweet potato. If you're a veg-head order this and thank me later. I got it without cheese/dressing on the side, and it was perfect. If you're vegan or dairy free they automatically give you oil on the side. For everyone else, a dollop of the garlic greek yogurt dressing is delicious. My friend ordered the chicken salad and loved every bite. Keep in mind the salads are big enough to share, so if you order your own you may end up with leftovers. Dessert also looked delicious, but we were too stuffed to try anything. What a perfect excuse to return!

See ya soon, Souvla!
author: Rachel S.

description: I got the worst food poisoning of my life here from the chicken. It's too bad because I've been to the other locations with no problem. Now I can't bring myself to go back
author: Eva W.

description: Amazingly delicious!! Great atmosphere too! I had the pork pita sandwich, Greek fries and their to die for frozen Greek yogurt with cherry sauce.
author: Nicci M.

description: This food is ok. People over hype this place. I got a wrap with lamb and a side of fries and it is just like any other Mediterranean wrap I have had. For the price and the hype, I expected more. This place is just another Greek spot, nothing more than people make it out to be. I would rate this a 2.5 stars but that's not allowed.
author: Walter R.

description:
With the ongoing NBA finals and the special start times to capture the largest possible viewing audience, eating before attending a Warriors' game can prove tricky.  A generous (monetary and time wise) friend, picked up meals here for our party of four.  Knowing my palate taste, she ordered the Mary's free range chicken salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Zyk4DtsdIIYqMUteQfBdJw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) for me.  
Due to traffic conditions and the 6 pm start time, I held off on eating this salad until after the game.  Our kind host and my other friend had the vegetarian salad which one touted as one of the best she's ever had.  Our host's dad enjoyed his healthy chicken salad too.
When I got home, I dug in with raised expectations.  The good news, the salad lived up to the hype.  The greens probably lacked the crunch due to the four hour delay from pre game to returning home but the flavors were still good.  The citrus added a kick to the protein, greens, and the even yet not overly savory dressing; there was something pickled in the salad which made.  
Probably didn't hurt that the Warriors won game one of the Finals in making that salad that much sweeeeter.  
Would have this salad again, but not sure whether I'll actually visit the restaurant given the neighborhood parking difficulties.  Nice addition to the neighborhood that's home for two of my favorite restaurants for burgers, French onion soup, and simple meals (Absinthe and Chez Papa).
author: Mike C.

description: The line was daunting, but the cause was great. While waiting, I polled my fellow supplicants about my choices: pork, lamb or chicken. Winner, winner was the chicken dinner. Number 2 was a split decision between pork and lamb. I bought all three. You have the choice between sandwich and salad. I got sandwich. The chicken was good, the orange slices were unexpected. Veggies were crisp. Chicken was shwarma-y. Awesome ? More "just good". The lamb was tasty. Fat was well rendered, the spicing was good. But frankly ? A little over cooked. I am saving the pork for the morning. I got a side of fries, and they were nice and crispy, with a sprinkle of feta. Good. Not great. I don't get what the fuss is about. The food did not live up to the line. It seemed more like a neighborhood joint, and I wouldn't make the trip if there was a shwarma shack nearby. Makes me wonder why SF is so ga-ga over this place. Meh.
author: Vish N.

description: Souvla has never disappointed! Their wraps are delicious (pork is less dry than lamb). I usually order in but went to the Hayes location recently and was pleased. Plenty of seats and really clean. Our food came out quick and was exactly like how I've ordered it before. Haven't tried the frozen yoghurt yet.
author: A. P.

description: Came just for the frozen Greek yogurt with baklava crumbles and honey syrup and was not disappointed! The tartness of the Greek yogurt balances perfectly with the baklava and honey, so it wasn't overly sweet for my palate. If you want something more on the savory side, try their frozen Greek yogurt with olive oil and sea salt. Even though there was a line, service was quick and friendly. Overall a great experience at the Hayes Valley location!
author: Ariel Y.

description:
After our training, we were leaving and our awesome driver coworker was telling us about the food places in Hayes area and he was telling us about this joint. 

There wasn't a line until we were in line and the line went out the door. When the line is out the door... it means it's good. You can have a salad or sandwich, with lamb, beef, chicken, or vegetarian. They have Greek fries and potatoes and other delicious sides. Let me just tell you, the fries never made it back to the office. 

Me and another coworker got a lamb sandwich to share, my half tasted a little dry but my coworker loved it. I loved the greens and the sauce inside the sandwich. 

Oh right, the bathroom is nice and clean. When the bathroom is clean, it means the restaurant is clean too. There are seating outside and some seats inside. 

I recommend it if you like Greek food!
author: Eugenia W.

description:
I really like the idea of this place. Quick and easy. Sometimes I just want a fast but tasty meal. I don't need eating to be a whole affair all the time. After a couple hours at the MOMA, the bestie and I came here for a delicious but light lunch as we were going to get boba afterwards. We got a chicken salad to share which they split for us! How nice. They gave a good amount of toppings so it didn't feel like it was just salad. I noticed how some reviews said the dressing was too heavy or how the salad is bland. I thought it was really tasty and yes they do drench on the dressing but just ask for it on the side. 

We got a greek yogurt and it was freaking delicious. What I liked was that they gave us the receipt and had us pick up the yogurt after we ate our salad so the yogurt wouldn't melt.  I went through a fro-yo crave and generally got the regular fro-yo. This greek yogurt gave all those pink berry and pink berry wannabes a run for their money. We got the honey one which I would suggest you avoid as the honey doesn't go well with a cold item. The seating can be a bit tight but I feel like if you wait a bit something will free up.
author: Sarah C.

description: Meh, salad was good but the dressing wasn't , the lamb isn't your traditional lamb you want at a Greek place, was expecting a "shawarma" style, and it was more like a stew lamb. So overall I wasn't impressed.
author: Deezy P.

description:
Why wait in a crazy line for brunch when you can get a delicious lunch almost immediately? I find lunch places to be underrated on weekends and almost always undersubscribed. 

Enter Souvla - fast, yummy and what seems to be pretty healthy. The pork salad is both hearty and yet not overfilling - and the roast chicken one is also quite good. If your heart is set on starches I recommend the fries; the sandwich is decidedly less good than the salad. (Not typically my approach)

Add a bottle of their $27 Greek rose and a baklava and honey topped frozen yogurt and you've got yourself one hell of a meal. If it's a nice day outside Patricia's green and the ample seating in Hayes Valley is a great place to enjoy your meal. Otherwise swoop in on any open seat in the restaurant itself; the skylights give the space a super nice ambience during the day.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
so far my favorite greek place in the city. 

you really cannot go wrong with what they have. it's simply amazing. i especially love their lamb salad. it's that kind of meal that you can't stop eating. you eat a huge portion. but you don't feel guilty about it! 

i definitely would recommend this place. and don't get me started and their yogurt. everything yes!! i could shed a tear for that creamy, richness.
author: Tina Y.

description: Terrible! The guy that took our order ordered the wrong dish and I tried asking them to fix it and the new girl who by then was taking orders said it's against policy to reorder or refund and I was not about to argue with her in that tiny space they n front of all the other guests. Just wow!!!
author: Melisa T.

description: Very yummy food, super cute place! We had the chicken sandwich, lamb salad and fries. All of them were exceptionally tasty! I will definitely be back next time I visit San Fran!
author: Gizem Z.

description: I really enjoyed this place! I really loved the chicken gyro as it was so good, and I also loved the frozen yogurt desert at the end! My parents and my brother also tried the other gyros of the different meats, and they seemed to enjoy the different varieties of meats of the different ones! I think that maybe I should try the lamb gyro ext time as I tested that one out from my mother, and it tastes so good and delicious! This place definitely deserves 5 stars for its good quality!
author: Asher D.

description:
GET THE BAKLAVA FROYO! Yum! 

Ordered: 
Chicken salad - A little too much dressing for my taste, but the ingredients were fresh and went together very well. Chicken breast was tender and moist and went perfectly with the veggies. Next time I'd order dressing on the side. 

Baklava Greek Yogurt - This thing will keep me coming back! The yogurt itself has a little bit of tartness, but goes amazingly well with the sweet syrup and baklava. I'm still dreaming about this dessert! 

A good healthy alternative. I'd be back to check out other items on the menu.
author: Michelle C.

description: The pork salad and sandwich here were just alright. All I really tasted from the salad bowl was the feta cheese, and I think they could've done a looot more with the pork to make it more juicy, tender, and flavorful. On the bright side, however, the veggies were fresh and the portions were generous. Service was also pretty quick and restaurant atmosphere was pleasant, albeit a bit cramped.
author: Amy C.

description: Good, not great. Relatively inexpensive, good portions but pretty bland and unoriginal- which isn't a bad thing. I've been 10-15 times and have no problem going back, but I don't go out of my way
author: Rex L.

description:
Where has Souvla been all my life?

You can't go wrong with the chicken or the lamb or the frozen Greek yogurt! The rotisserie chicken as a salad is my love. For a carnivore who hates veggies, kale never tasted so delicious. The combination of dressing and chicken flavor masks the fact that I'm eating greens. So not only did I eat healthy, it was tasty!

Ok, I forgot about the garlic fries. I usually prefer skinny fries but the quality of fries is amazing. Super crispy and not too garlicky and yum to the tum.

Cleanse the palate with some yogurt, of course. I had with baklava crumbles and I'm addicted. It's crack.

I love you, Souvla!
author: Nitar L.

description:
They have the fastest services in the world, maybe! You order a gyro or something, and right when you sit, it's gonna be there.. You order right when you get to the place. 

Location is great; close to Smitten IceCream. Food is 4/5.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
Meh. There are not a lot of menu options and what we ordered wasn't spectacular. If I am in Hayes Valley I would go to Papito's before coming back here. I had the salad with pork which was great, but it was just wayyy too oily. And the fries with cheese were good but there was hardly any cheese on it.

I'm glad I tried it but am not dying to come back. Their yogurts look good.

The place is small so get there early or be prepared to wait. It's also first come-first serve. Order at the counter and find a spot wherever you can. Fortunately, there is a lot of turnover so you can find a spot before your food comes. There is also family style in the middle. It's small, packed, cramped, and crowded.
author: Jess A.

description: Came here for dessert on a Friday night around 9pm. There was a relatively long line out the door, but it moved very fast. We got the Baklava Crumble & Honey Greek Yogurt, which was fantastic! I had tried something similar at another Mediterranean restaurant in the South Bay, and this was definitely comparable, perhaps even better. The baklava was soft but still chewy, with the perfect balance of nuts and honey. The greek yogurt was not too flavorful either, and was a great complement to the baklava. I would definitely come back for lunch/dinner, and of course, for the dessert again!
author: Puja S.

description: One minute reviews: It's about as overhyped as a stag do in Mykonos and just about as bland.
author: Steven S.

description: We grabbed takeout for four and ate in the small park beside the restaurant. It was lunch on a weekday so it was very busy but our order was well handled. Tasty if expensive for lunch.
author: Phillip D.

description: For hours after I ate a chicken bowl at soulva " that was so good, I feel really good" I would kill to learn the what herbs are in the oil dressing, I have eaten at many Greek restaurants this was by far the very best herbs and oil. The chicken also easy the tastiest I have had. LOVE THIS PLACE FIVE BIG FAT STARS
author: Felice C.

description:
Coming from Toronto which is famous for Mediterranean cuisine and its "Taste of the Danforth" Greek festival, I've always been disappointed in SF's greek food game. That said I was pretty excited to try this place but each time I've been here was a less than mediocre experience.

The toppings for the chicken wrap is a creative combination of flavors. The orange is a nice touch; however, they are pretty conservative with the toppings. And I can't say I'm impressed with the rotisserie chicken. I've had it a few times and it's consistently bland and dry which is really atypical for rotisserie chicken so I don't know what their problem is.

The fries are a scam. Avoid it. They're $4 and the description paints this picture of these fancy fries with olive oil, lemon juice, cheese, and parsley on it. BUT IT'S A LIE. You don't taste ANY of that because they only put on a microscopic amount (same deal with the wrap). It might as well be plain fries. So I ask a server about sauce and apparently it's an extra dollar. So then you have to wait in a big line again just for some sauce while your food gets cold. Then the $1 sauce is hella tiny, only good for like 3/4 of the fries even if you're a conservative dipper. If you're liberal dipper you'll probably need 3. And no, they don't have ketchup.

As for portions, they don't work for me. The wrap is too small and the fries are too big. I can't finish both but I'll feel unsatisfied after just the wrap. For $12 "fast food" I think that's unacceptable. And I'm definitely not the only yelper who feels the same way.

Another annoying thing about this place: it seems to always be busy and people are always hella gunner when getting a seat. I always see people sitting down without order numbers and I'm just standing around holding a number in a super congested area like an idiot, servers constantly trying to get around me. Look, if a place is full, you don't get to sit down before ordering. We've ordered. We need a place to eat. Wait your freaking turn.

On the other hand, the frozen greek yogurt with baklava is really great and that's really all I come here for.
author: Andrew D.

description:
This review is for the salad bowls we had a few weeks ago and today's frozen greek yogurt. 

What a Souvla filled day today, went to the Souvla for lunch on Divisadero and on my attempt to walk off the lunch, I was lured into Souvla on Hayes for a frozen greek yogurt topped with baklava and honey. For $5 this fro greyo is the bomb. I had the intent to eat half and save the other half for my boyfriend. Oh how that intention got derailed during my 5 min walk home. It was melting so fast that I had to eat it all... I mean what is a girl suppose to do when you have a delicious melting frozen greek yogurt? Eat it faster right? Needless to say, this was awesome and guilt free so I'll be back for more, next time with the boyfriend in attendance. 

On a Thursday night a few weeks ago, we came and ordered one superior farms lamb leg salad and one Mary's free range salad. I've always loved the vibe and the colorful salad bowls, but when we got ours we were highly disappointed with the meat quality in the salad. Maybe it was late at night and only end meat shaving were left. Also they were short on ingredients, cucumbers were out for the night. Not a bad thing to experience as this shows that ingredients are fresh. However, I would have loved to have a substitution for the missing cucumbers seeing that I removed the cheese as well due to lactose intolerance. So my salad was looking a little sad. 

Likely will go back to the Divisadero location for a meal but will continue to come back to Hayes for dessert. 

Overall: 
Food/ drinks: 2/5 for salad bowls; 5/5 for greek frozen yogurt 
Service: 1/5 - felt rushed through the ordering process and throughout the entire meal as a waiter came to take our bowls away about 3 times during our dine in while there was vivd amounts of food still in the bowls. 
Environment:  2/5- great decor, free wifi and self seating, self water service, clean the tables yourself, music is way too loud for conversations
author: Janice K.

description: I like Souvla a lot! Food is delicious and prices are reasonable. Perfect for a quick dinner date. It's always packed, so you better plan ahead!
author: Giedre P.

description: The waiter was just horrible. Served me with a plate I didn't order and refused to give me what I did order. The chicken in the salad could have been anything else. Just disgusting. This is absolutely a place I'll avoid. Mainly for the messed up service.
author: Robert M.

description:
Oh My Freakin' Goodness!

My tastebuds and mind has been blown away! Not only is the food amazing, but the speed in which they get the food out to you is amazing! Ever since I moved up to SF from SJ, this place has been on my list of "To-Try" for some time now. One day I visited Hayes Valley for my casual city exploration adventure, and there I happened to stumble upon this huge line. And knowing me, I was so curious as to what the heck was going on! I later found out that the huge line was for this amazing beauty! 

I ordered the lamb sandwich for $13 and the frozen greek yogurt with honey & baklava for $5. Definitely the best combo I have ever had! I would totally recommend 100% of the time!
author: Benson M.

description: This is quite possibly the best sandwich I've ever had. The pork just melts in your mouth and the pita tastes like they just pulled it out of the oven. This is well worth $14. YUM
author: Molly O.

description: I got the Greek fries with garlic sauce on the side and wish I'd had a bath tub full of them. They were perfectly crispy and well seasoned. I wish the cheese was melted on instead of just sprinkled on after, because it ended up just falling to the bottom. I want to come back to try their food and Greek yogurt. Loved the decor and vibe too!
author: Sara T.

description:
I wish I lived closer to Souvla so I could take more advantage of it. It's a great grab-and-go Mediterranean place, where you can get a fantastic chicken salad in less than 10 minutes. The chicken salad, which I've had twice, features juicy rotisserie chicken, onions, feta cheese, and tangerines. It may be a salad, but it's just big enough to be filling without making you feel overly full -- the perfect size!

There's a decent amount of seating inside, as well as a few tables outside. It's always pretty packed but you can usually grab a seat if you hang around for a little while. Ambience is very casual (you order and pay at a counter), which is great for a low-key hangout with a friend or if you're looking to grab something quick on the way home.

Great for those nights when you're just looking for something fast, fresh, and delicious without too much effort or fuss.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Full review (finally got here for a meal)

The sandwich is the way to go..ask for it "Greek stylel" and they ad French fries to the sandwich "WHAT!!"

We spilt a lamb sandwich - Greek style, a pork salad (the pork was a bit on the dry side - but the salad was really yummy), some Greek fries, and OF COURSE that froyo with the baklava - my FAV.

Oh and we got a couple glasses of a sparking red wine that was perfect. 

You really need to have a friend with you to help scout out a spot to sit while the other person orders. Service is pretty fast.

Great place for "booze sponge" eating. YUM and done.
author: Amy W.

description:
Quick background: 
The chef and founder used to work at the upscale Greek restaurant, Kokkari, and you can definitely taste echoes of the finer fare at Soulva.

Best items:
Greek yogurt with olive oil and sea salt. Do yourself a favor and get two if you're with a date. Splitting it will only make you sad when the experience is over.

Fries: get the granch sauce. The fries are doubled fried, thick, and awesome.

The gyros were okay. Meat was really soft and well marinated. The overall composition was a touch dry. Pour some granch on it and you'll be good to go.
author: Peter T.

description: A great salad! Its simple but oh so good. Don't even get me started on the fries. YUM. Super good take out option for sitting in the park :)
author: Amanda H.

description:
Simple menu, simple concept, delicious food. 

Souvla puts a nice modern spin on Mediterranean food. Flavors were light and bright, much like being on the beach on the Mediterranean. 

We tried the chicken salad, potatoes and chicken sandwich. The chicken is tender and seasoned just enough. The salad also included kale, romaine, shaved fennel, sliced oranges and pickled onions. The colors were beautiful and every ingredient had a purpose and made sense. The balance was perfect.

The sandwich was pretty much the salad inside of a piece of pita bread. Can't go wrong, especially with a fluffy cloud wrapped around your sandwich! 

The winning dish: the juicy potatoes. Considering the potatoes are dressed in chicken drippings, the flavors are surprisingly light and bright. Absolutely delicious. 

Finished off with the cherry frozen Greek yogurt. I won't even talk about it, just get it. 

Great sunlight. Nice amount of seating. And a bevy of cute young people to look at. My kind of place.

Will definitely be coming back to try other proteins. And the French fries are calling my name!
author: Preston M.

description:
I love Hayes Valley as much as I love finding new spots to eat. I was drawn to Souvla because I love BAKLAVA. So imagine combing frozen greek yogurt + baklava = genius!

So I payed a visit one Wednesday night and found Souvla to be very dark inside and somewhat cramped. The roasting meats on the rotisserie looked inviting but I wasn't too fond of the place. 

But I wasn't there to eat dinner. I came there for the yogurt with baklava. The verdict? Well it had a nice tart flavor that complimented the sweet baklava. But it wasn't really the best baklava I've had. Also the yogurt wasn't too frozen and melted easily.

Idk I wouldn't mind trying again IF I had a craving but I'm not in a hurry to rush back. I'd rather go to Baskin and Robbins lol.
author: Ralph N.

description: This review is only for their greek frozen yogurt! It's so good--so creamy and not overly sweet. I love how you can just walk up to the counter and get it to go. Make sure to ask for extra honey syrup! Baklava adds a nice texture to it.
author: Anna H.

description: Best recommendation ever!! I've been long overdue for Greek food and this sandwich spot fits the bill!!
author: Blaque V.

description:
The froyo with rich, syrupy olive oil and sea salt is like a dense cloud drizzled in unicorn juice. You should get this.

I live a stone's throw away from Souvla and it is incredibly dangerous. I contemplate getting it at least 4 times a week and act on those impulses at least twice a week. I tried the vegetarian sandwich a while ago and was underwhelmed; it was too starchy for my taste and I wished there was another protein option. 

Fast forward a few months, and I finally decided to try the increasingly popular froyo. Fast forward a few weeks from that point, and I'm sure I've single handedly helped pay a small operating expense for Souvla with my froyo purchases.

Froyo is $4.35 after tax.
author: Rachel I.

description:
I could go here every week.  My goto dish is the lamb salad.  The service is quick and the line usually isn't too long. 

Only thing I wish is the price was about 10% lower and there was about 10% more lamb on each portioning.  But we live in SF and I know that's probably unreasonable!

Parking here is hit or miss, so I recommend walking or taking the bus.  Souvla sits in the heart of the busy Hayes neighborhood, which is metered, but I've always had to drive around the block a few times anytime I drove. 

Great gluten-free and paleo lunch spot!
author: John S.

description: My favorite neighborhood spot! Mix and match the salad set ups/meats. Get Greek style (fries on top) for an extra 50 cents. Get the Greek yogurt. The veggie setup is a teeny bit salty for me (maybe better without olives) but the various other setups are all tasty AF.
author: Max K.

description: The Greek yogurt with baklava was amazing.  Went for a late night treat and it was fantastic.  Great service and great value. Friendly staff
author: Ronda S.

description:
This is my favorite place in the area. I've been multiple times and have tried most of the salads and sandwiches and here are my top 3 recommended things:

1) The lamb sandwich. It's sooo good. If you're trying to be healthy, the lamb salad is a good alternative. 
2) The Greek fries with harissa-spiced yogurt. The fries are really good and the sauce pairs incredibly well. 
3) Any of the frozen greek yogurts. All. So. Good.

Combine all three above, and you'll be extremely full and happy for less than $25.

On the place itself, expect a line, though service is quick, and unless it's a weekend night you should be able to find a seat within 10-15 minutes.
author: Tanay J.

description:
Best thing here has got to be the frozen greek yogurt! I got the one with baklava on top and it was so delicious, probably my favorite frozen yogurt I've ever had. Definitely worth more than $5! Also, very good with olive oil and seas salt.

On the other hand, food is good, but not
Great. I had the pork pita wrap sandwich and it was really bland. I was excited for the mint yogurt, but the mint taste was not detectable. Some sauce on the side would really take this up a notch. Also, the pita bread they use isn't anything special. Using a fresher/fluffier/softer bread would make this much better as well. Pickled onions were a nice touch though!

I recently tried the salads and think they are much better than the wraps, especially the veggie salad!

The line goes by really fast, so don't be discouraged by a line out the door. Indoor seating is limited, so I recommend getting food to go!
author: Kimia M.

description:
Had yianni's loukaniko for brunch here. It was pretty good! The yogurt on top was smooth, and not too sour cream tasting. The cheese, onions and bell peppers were a good combination, and the sausage was fragrant, just strangely kind of tough to eat.

I've tried their sea salt and olive oil Greek yogurt. The yogurt itself is amazing, the oil is the most fragrant, pleasantly surprising part of this item, but I think the sea salt is pretty overwhelming. If you're looking for something sweet, go for the baklava frozen yogurt. The baklava is rich and delicious, and complements the cool, sweetness of the yogurt well. 

I usually, 100% will never order salad, but I make an exception at Souvla. Their pork shoulder salad is delicious, and it will last you 2 meals. The cheese on top is not too strong, and everything is a blend of incredibly healthy kale and other good greens. I have no idea what the dressing consists of, but it's light tasting and really enhances the salad in the right way. I'm willing to come back and try the chicken one (the pork in this salad tastes faintly like pulled pork without BBQ sauce)
author: Ke C.

description:
Was absolutely blown away by this little spot. I have a soft spot for all food Mediterranean and the flavors here had that solid Mediterranean food taste but with a modern twist to it. 

Came here on a weekday night for take-out and you just choose your meat, and then whether you want it in sandwich or salad form. I got the sandwich although I've heard the salad is just as good. I got Mary's Free-Range Chicken with "granch" dressing, fennel, navel orange, pickled red onion, pea shoots, mizithra cheese. I am usually not a fan of putting citruses into my savory entrees but the blend of everything here with the super juicy chicken was AH-MAZING! Also got their Greek Fries and mmm...you definitely do not want to miss these. 

They also have frozen greek yogurt here with the most delicious sounding toppings (baklava crumbles, wildflower honey?!) but I just came from Loving Cup but next time!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Definitely a repeat on my list of places to go to at lunch! Hearty tasty salad and a satisfying fries to unhealthy it up and to pack on more calories you can indulge on their baklava frozen yogurt. I'm definitely going back to try other food, but it's definitely a nice refreshing taste - portions are very filling and but not overwhelmingly too much. My only downside is the wait, the line and small space and sometimes it can get too cold to enjoy... But other than that, food is great. Can't say much for service since it's paid at order and just a quick hand of your food once ready... But it wasn't bad service either, so the one star less is just for the length of time in line/getting food and lack of seating. Food only critique is an "A+"
author: M M.

description:
Everything I know about the Greek culture, I learned from My Big Fat Greek Wedding: Windex solves all problems. Greeks are basically Trinidadians, except one of us is on steroids. If I knew anything about my own culture I'd give you a final verdict, but I don't, so you have to figure it out yourself. 

My friends parents, who are the loveliest parentals, treated us to a concert at the Nourse Theater and we wanted to meet up for dinner before. This spot seemed to be the best option health wise and I'm so glad we picked it. 

The lines get long very fast, but it moves at a good clip. The one con is really limited seating: about four 4-tops, a community table that seats about 8, and bar style seating. I think there's a 2-top right outside. 

I had the Chicken salad and have yet to regret that choice. It comes with a nicely chopped kale/romaine mix, granch dressing, fennel, navel orange chunks, pickled red onions, and feta cheese. Oh man, I'm still salivating thinking about this. Their chicken is the best roasted chicken I've had in SF. The only competitor in my humble opinion is Bell Street Farm in Los Alamos. I believe you can order a whole chicken to go too, but if I'm not mistaken it's $20 and that's overpriced. 

We also tried the Greek fries, and the juicy potatoes. The latter was OMG GET IN MAH BELLY. I might have said this out loud. Drink wise we popped a bottle of Greek Bubbles which was really nice, not too dry and really refreshing. Another table had the rose and hated it. We also had the floral & spicy red, which was as described.
author: Bianca B.

description: I'd skip the food which is just okay and just get the yogurt which tastes like frozen Greek yogurt.
author: Annie P.

description: I went here to get a gyro. They don't have them, but they do have a very good lamb peta. It had a very refreshing taste, but I think it was a little expensive for the size of the meal. The feta roasted chicken looked delicious though. I definitely would go back and try that the next time. The service was very quick though and it is great if you want something to go.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Mediterranean food is my favorite and unfortunately for me, this cuisine is generally a sore subject in San Francisco. I lived in Chicago for 6 years: home to a vibrant Greektown, real deal Lebanese shawarma, and more falafel than you can shake an olive stick at. So yeah - I miss it immensely!

Anyway, after much trial and error, I've finally found really, REALLY great spit-fired meats (and being of Croatian heritage, I grew up on backyard spit-roasted lambs and pigs so I know my stuff). Souvla, you are the new 'it' kid in the Mediterranean (Greek to be more specific) category! Yes, it's pricey but I don't mind paying for a menu based on natural, vegetarian-fed meats from animals raised in a sustainable environment. 

I had a salad topped with pork that blew my mind... a bed of Romaine and kale topped with a very generous amount of American Homestead pork shoulder, cherry tomatoes, pickled red onion, thinly-sliced cucumber, and feta cheese all tossed with a minted Greek yogurt dressing. The portion was large and could easily serve as two meals if you start with the Avgolemono soup.

And this sensational soup deserves its own paragraph: the classic Greek recipe is elevated with white mean chicken, buttery rice, and the perfect egg-lemon broth. This rendition is overwhelmingly crave-worthy... on the small side, but I'll definitely get it again. 

Souvla, you really hit it out of the park! I'll look forward to trying the olive oil yogurt next time. And a note to the owner: please open a location in SOMA or the FiDi!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
3.5 stars.  While planning my trip to San Francisco, I definitely wanted to try this place since there are no locations in my area.  I knew exactly what I wanted to try...the lamb salad, juicy potatoes, and black cherry Greek soda.  All were pretty delicious!  They give a great amount of lamb!

It was very busy when I went on a weekday at lunch time, but I was able to grab the best seat in the house...the small, front corner nook!  No other restarant I've been to has a little area like that.  If there was a location close to me, I'd like to try a few other items.
author: Rolena I.

description: Food is excellent and well priced. Staff are awesome. Christopher went out of his way to accommodate our order. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Annie G.

description:
Came here after an intense yoga class at Ritual and gotta say, it was the perfect meal to end the night. 

Lamb salad: light but hardy. Lamb is cut up into bite sized squares and there's plenty of it. I only managed to finish half and I was starving when I started the meal. 

Frozen yogurt: my friend and I concluded that this choice was healthy. It's frozen Greek yogurt after all. I had the wildflower honey and he had the cherry. Both super light and super "healthy" tasting.  ;)

Vibe: at close to 9pm, the place was packed. But I found it to be cozy and the decor very inviting. 

Can't wait to try the other stuff on the menu!
author: Emily Y.

description:
Was in Hayes Valley when I remembered a friend recommended Souvla a while ago. The restaurant was pretty small, but really clean and well-decorated. Eucalyptus branches on the table and white tiling just make you want to stay there for hours and hours. 

In terms of food, I wasn't too hungry so all I had were Greek fries. They were good but still a bit pricey all things considered. I'd come back to try the frozen Greek yogurt and the main dishes though!
author: Tina X.

description:
I live in the area and every time I pass Souvla, it's jam packed full of people. One night I decide to give the restaurant a try. I ordered up the pork sandwich and a side order of their fries. I was pretty excited as I hadn't had Greek food in quite sometime and I love that combo of tender salty meat with that cooling yogurt effect. 

Foods up!  I dig in. The salad of tomato, cucumber, and greens inside the sandwich wasn't bad, but definitely needed some seasoning. Maybe the vinaigrette bottle wasn't shaken well enough before it was put in the salad bowl. The pork, although tender, was lacking seasoning as well and had a pretty mild taste unfortunately. The fries were soggy and pretty average as well. 

Overall the quality of food vs. the price point isn't worth it. I really wanted to like this place and find a quick casual eatery in my hood.
author: Josh S.

description:
Souvla is pretty close to perfect. There's a reason why it's always buzzing with people. Their lamb leg sandwich is phenomenal, even though it's on the pricier side ($13) for a gyro/sandwich. It's filled with fresh ingredients and will keep you full for hours. The juicy potatoes are cooked in rotisserie drippings, which means you'll probably not want to share.

It's easily a $20+ meal, or more if you order their frozen Greek yogurt. While I loved the consistency of the fro-yo, I wouldn't order honey as a topping again...it hardened quickly and I was basically scooping chunks of honey into my mouth. The sour cherry is calling my name!

One drawback is its popularity. Fighting for a table is never fun, but you may need to do some shameless hovering to grab a seat. It's a cramped restaurant and lines are often out the door.
author: Valerie L.

description: Salads are pretty good. A little pricey. It's all good though. What isn't good is this big piece of plastic that I found in my food. Their workers might be on auto-pilot HOWEVER, please pay attention to what you're doing. How could you miss this plastic wrapping in my food???
author: Ro R.

description:
4 stars overall, but I think Souvla had the potential to be a 4.5 or 5 star place. I had the pork wrap and was very impressed at the tenderness and rich pork-y flavor. Yes, the wrap is huge and unwieldy and drips all over, but recognize that that grease dripping out of your wrap is melted animal fat, i.e., liquid deliciousness! So I say keep your head down, enjoy that luscious animal fat, and file Souvla away in your head as not a good first date place.

The wrap wasn't perfect, though. Ours came out slightly warmer than room temp and I can only imagine how much more amazing it would be if it had been hot. Same with the pita - it was on the hard end and lacked fluffiness. Again, the whole wrap would have been elevated with those small details.

Still, all the ingredients were fresh and tasty. It's not the cheapest fare ($11/wrap), but you get what you pay for at Souvla.

Also: note that it gets incredibly busy around dinner time, so scout out tables after you place your order!
author: Clarice W.

description:
"Wow" is the word I would use to describe this place. One of the best Mediterranean places in San Francisco. As the main course they have two options a sandwich or salad and 3-4 different types of meat. It is an even tie between the sandwiches and salads if you are going with atleast 1 other person I would highly recommend splitting a sandwich and salad and getting the chance to try both.

The lamb sandwich is very different from most places it has very fresh ingredients, great sauce added to it and overall a great find.

To top off the meal a must try is the olive oil and salt greek yogurt. It sounds like a unusual combination but the different textures go very well together.

I would def recommend trying this place.
author: Kunal T.

description: Ever since I discovered Avgelomeno Soup in my first San Francisco neighborhood years ago, Ive been OBSESSED. So I was more than excited to try it here on my first visit. it did NOT disappoint. IMO soups like these are every antidote to a chilly or stressful city day. Not that this day was that, beautiful warm and sunny and lunch with my BFF since high school. Just sayin. The salad was ok, I didn't like the meat actually. I think I ordered pork. It was kinda tough and chewy. The juicy potatoes were addictive and the greek bottle of white wine we ordered was fantastic!! and a good white is always a challenge to obtain in my experience. Yay for another great dining option on Hayes. oh and Good service too! Love the little patio out back.
author: May C.

description: Best frozen Greek yogurt I've ever tasted in my life!!! Okay maybe one day I'll go to Greece and have some yogurt but right now this place takes the cake. The salads were pretty good too. I liked my bf's pork salad better than my chicken one though. The meat was so tender. I also liked the creamy dressing and the salad that came with it. We ordered a side of fries but it was just okay, nothing special. I just know that I'll be back for the Greek yogurt because it was amazing.
author: Brittany D.

description: I've lived in Turkey and Greece for two years. This is not authentic mediterranean food. It's overpriced american fusion garbage. The meat is oily, the dressing is excessive, the pricing is completely out of proportion to the actual quality of the food. You can do much better with your money elsewhere.
author: Jenny R.

description: The quality of the food is good but $16 for a lamb sandwich with no sides is absolutely ridiculous.
author: Marissa R.

description:
I had high hopes for this restaurant. I love Greek food, have been to Greece, and have read the owner here is from The French Laundry! It's super cute inside and the entire menu sounded delicious. The problem was execution. My sandwich was so stuffed full of meat and not enough of anything else. The chicken was much too dry as well. There needs to be less meat, more sauce, more veggies, and better bread. I left the majority of my sandwich on the plate. 
Greek fries were very tasty even though they were served kind of cold and the cheese was all on the bottom of the cup. 

Baklava crumbles and Greek yogurt was pretty good. That was my favorite thing and I give it a solid 4 stars. 

I wouldn't come back. I spent $23 for average food when I could have had a schwarma elsewhere for $8 and been much happier.
author: Jen B.

description: Expected better to what I paid and read on reviews however its a nice place to go. Food is good and fresh. I had lamb Gyro wrap and wish they could marinate meat tastier! Tried greek fries with garlic deep liked it. I got yogurt with baklava crumble, worthed it to try and you may like it but sour and sweet contrast isn't my favorite, I believe baklava crumble serve on plain greek milk soft serve would tastes better. I tried a small bottle of greek beer, nice and light to drink but again not sure if it worths $6! I had side greek salad, loved it.
author: Ali N.

description: So delicious and so much food.  There's always a line out the door but they moved quick and our food came out fast and hot and oh so so good. Definitely need to try the Greek yogurt with baklava topping
author: Margo B.

description: In love with the Greek frozen yogurt! I got the baklava crumbles, and my friend tried the olive oil and sea salt -- both amazing! Definitely will be back for that. We got it to-go and spent the afternoon eating it at the park across the street.
author: Priya B.

description:
Frozen Greek Yogurt?!? I never knew that existed!! It's like froyo, but more tart and greek yogurt tasting. Be sure to get the one topped with baklava and honey -- your taste buds will be in heaven! I was secretly annoyed that my friend kept stealing huge bites of my yogurt....

The salad is also amazing! The chicken is so flavorful and tender and I was surprisingly very full after eating about half the sandwich. Of course, to counterbalance the healthy salad, I ordered a side of fries. They're seasoned deliciously as well!

I can't wait to come back and eat more frozen greek yogurt!
author: Janet H.

description:
Every once in a while, I try a place everyone else is raving about and find myself shrugging my shoulders in a state of meh-ness. Oh who am I kidding? It happens all the time, and then I get all snarky when people hate on something that they have deemed less than satisfactory. Well, I've now tried Souvla, and I must say I don't really get the hype. It's a shame because I like the bare-bones, In-n-Out concept used - focus on three meats, add a veggie option (sweet potato, not tofu, in this case) and throw in some froyo to get more walk-by traffic. I think a lot of my meh reaction came from the poor way they handled the crowds there. Which basically means not at all.

The compact place crowds quickly, and the overflow is left to the busy sidewalk where the variety of Hayes Valley life forms gets all in your face. From the shrieking loon smelling of urine to the smug, entitled bitch tapping her iPhone expecting me to get out of her way. It takes all kinds to gorge a gyros, doesn't it? Jamie W. and I decided to order our food to go, though he ended up going on a scavenger hunt for a couple of Diet Cokes since Souvla refuses to sell them. He decided to try the Superior Farms Lamb Leg in a Salad ($14), the priciest option on the menu, with chunks of lamb marinated in harissa-spiked yogurt and mixed with cucumber, radish, pickled red onion and feta cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/1ve0YsT).

It was pretty good since they mixed in kale with the lettuce, but it needed a bit more kick. Since we already secured our bench on Patricia's Green, it was too bad nobody told us to stock up on hot sauce. Mine was marginally disappointing, the $11 American Homestead Pork Shoulder in a Wrap. The fancy meat was rather sparse compared to the breadiness of the pita almost to the point that it tasted near-vegetarian with cherry tomato, cucumber, pickled red onion and feta cheese. The sweetness of the minted Greek yogurt wasn't helping matters much either (photo:  http://bit.ly/1y4XdXA). Honestly, the $4 side of Greek Fries was the most satisfying part of my meal as they were doused with lemon juice, olive oil, and mizitrha cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/1zfasmS). Perhaps I'll go back for take two when it's slow...whenever that is.

FOOD - 3 stars...upscale Greek fast food priced for Hayes Valley with the salad more satisfying than the wrap
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...too crowded to notice really
SERVICE - 2 stars...chaos control needed
TOTAL - 3 stars...kinda like a Spice Kit for the ooom-pah crowd
author: Ed U.

description:
Mmm yum yum! My friends and I decided to stop by this place on our way home from brunch mostly because my roommates love this place and I was just infatuated by the NY style coffee cups.

I got the frozen greek yogurt with baklava crumbles. It really is froyo textured greek yogurt but with the same greek yogurt flavors. The baklava was good but I actually found that it made the froyo a little too sweet for my liking because they sprinkle it on top as opposed to spreading it throughout the yogurt. If it was interspersed better, it might work better. I liked it enough though! It's basically an even healthier version of froyo right? frozen greek yogurt and all. It literally just tastes like froyo ... but less flavorful which I kinda liked on a hot Saturday afternoon.

tldr; they have the cool new york style coffee cups !!! but otherwise, the frozen greek yogurt is pretty good!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
First of all, why don't we have more Greek restos in SF? Souvla is so popular, and obviously we could have more of these more casual Greek eateries as well as fancier places. 

On Monday of this week, Souvla was packed by 6pm, and looked to be in for a super busy night. I had a glass of rose, a super generous pour for $10, and my food came to $10 also - for a bowl of ye olde traditional chicken egg lemon soup and an order of fries. The fries are WORLD CLASS and the soup delicious. Plenty of food for $10!

Will visit again for sure.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Souvla is a great Greek option in Hayes Valley. They have fantastic salads as well as gyros/wraps. I usually get the lamb gyro and the lady likes the chicken salad. They also have a pork and sweet potato option in addition to lamb/chicken. 

Their ingredients are very fresh and high quality. 

Eating there is fun because they are very generous with their wine pours and have some tasty Greek wines. 

There's often a line but it moves fast so don't let that discourage you.
author: Farid V.

description:
Souvla is a restaurant that I wish was a staple: the food is very solid, and prices aren't too high. (Note: they're supposedly opening one in the Alamo square park area on divisadero sometime this year!)

I've had the pork salad two times and have enjoyed it both times--it is very flavorful with a nice sweet component from the pork and a saltiness from the cheese. It also feels like you get quite a bit for your money, as the portion is pretty big. Haven't had the froyo yet but hope to try it sometimes.

There isn't much seating, so be ready to prowl for a seat or take it to go. I've been lucky enough to get a seat both inside and outside (very limited outdoor seating). The line ideas usually pretty long, but service is pretty fast. Great option if your in the area and looking for a fresh meal.
author: Julia N.

description: Amazing Chicken Salad Definitely Coming Back!!! The greens were fresh and the chicken juicy!! I got it with hot sauce on the side but wow great work
author: Enjoy S.

description:
Not the worst - Not the best either ... 
The lamb sandwich has a good amount of lamb and the fries are pretty tasty ... Could have gone for a little tomato and extra yogurt sauce on my sandwich ... The $1 I spent on the garlic yogurt dip for my fries was sans garlic as far as we could tell ... The best part ? The Greek Cherry Soda ... From a bottle ... They didn't make it or anything ... IF - If I ever do go back it'll be to try the frozen yogurt ...
author: Misty R.

description:
Great place for a quick (if not too busy), informal Greek bite. Salad with the roasted chicken was addicting. The lamb gyro was filled with cucumber, pickled onion, and feta goodness. The frozen yogurt with the baklava crumbles was amazing. 

Whenever we're in the area we try to come by. Highly recommend.
author: Jerico M.

description:
Tough decision between sandwich and salad but went with salad since I was dining alone and wanted room for dessert (hello baklava crumbles on greek frozen yogurt!!!). 

The warm chicken on the cold salad was divine. Followed up with the perfectly sweet yogurt & chewy baklava crumbles, my heart and belly were so pleased. Walk it off strolling nearby shops. Great area and I will certainly return to Souvla!!
author: Mary P.

description:
Walked here for lunch, and it was great.  I had the lamb gyro and it was tasty and filling.  I got the fries as well, but couldn't eat them all as the gyro filled me up.  But, the fries were crispy and golden and perfectly salted.  

The tables are either a four top, or a large communal table inside, some bar style seating and a seats outside.  I felt perfectly comfortable as a woman alone here sitting at the communal table A+.
author: Victoria N.

description:
Highlights
- Frozen greek yogurt with baklava and sour cherry syrup: Order it! Thank goodness this place is not close to me otherwise, I'll be here every day for this addicting treat. The perfect amount of tart, sweet, and crunch. It's SO good, just do it and thank me later. 
- Greek fries w/ Garlic yogurt: I don't even think it needs any type of dipping sauce, because it tasted delicious by itself. Thick cut fries with the right amount of seasoning and salt. 

Improvements
- Chicken salad: I ordered with pita on the side, thanks yelper for the recommendation. Ingredients were fresh, but everything tasted oily and bland. The garlic yogurt dip for my fries made this salad a lot more tastier. 
- Seating was limited during dinner time on the Saturday evening that I came. Consider take out if you are pressed for time and don't want to wait for a seat. 
- The cashier was not friendly nor helpful when I asked for recommendations and the other employee that brought my to go order out to me totally redeemed everything by simply saying a "Thank you and have a nice evening."

Tip
- Don't even try to drive here on a weekend evening especially when there are also events going on around the vicinity. Parking is ridiculous especially during peak dinner hours. Uber, Lyft, Sidecar, carpool, etc...you get the deal, trust me!
author: Tracy T.

description:
Whoever wrote that this is a Greek place is mistaken. It's not Greek food. It may have a Greek name, it's not Greek.  

Having just holidayed in the Greek isles, I wanted a redo.  I was thoroughly seduced by the beauty of Santorini and the beaches of Mykonos, not to mention the millions of great meals I had day in and day out, I read somewhere this is a phenomenal Greek place and rushed over. 

It is not. it's San Francisco Greek, just like Dosa is San Francisco Indian and not real Southern Indian food. A real Southern Indian place ought to have upma, and a real Souvlaki ought to have the right type of texture with the best crunchy cucumbers. I have lost counts on how man souvlakies I had after drinking and partying all day (while on holiday, not on a regular basis), I can assure you this is not it. But.. San Francisco Greek is quite good, and in some cases, perhaps better, certainly healthier, tastier and more innovative. A real Greek salad will not be caught dead with lettuce. I learned that on my trip with my Greek friends. Their salad is super delicious but it has more than the usual Greek ingredients. The lamb souvlaki is way more tenderer than what I had gotten in Greece. 

The ambience though, reminds me of the trendier bars you'd see in Athens late at night. 

A winner. But like many great world cuisines, once it's in San Francisco, it takes on a new life, a face lift, and in the process, an ancient cuisine is reinvented to feed (and to fit) the tech workers of a city in transition.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Everybody needs to get their frozen yogurt with baklava crumble!! I love a good tart cup of froyo and they did not disappoint. The baklava sweetness complements really well with the yogurt tartness. 

We also ordered the chicken sandwich which was as good as the reviews made them out to be! I do wish they had a little more of the salad part (my last few bites we're just chicken and some dressing) but otherwise, would definitely come again!
author: Dora T.

description: Don't believe the rave reviews!  They enticed me to try it for the first time so $14 later the gyro I ordered arrived with dry, over-cooked, over-salted lamb in a thick, cold pita with at most a half-teaspoon of sauce.  It was like eating sawdust with sliced cucumbers which were the only moisture in the sandwich.  I would never go back.
author: Bob C.

description: Ordered a vegetarian salad to go for lunch . It was super efficient and the staff was really nice about getting me my food ASAP, even though they were busy. The salad itself wasn't the best and was definitely overpriced for what it was. Definitely willing to go back though, but I'll definitely be having something else.
author: Bisrat A.

description:
I loved Souvla! This hidden gem is a fantastic place to get your Greek food fix! They offer wrap and salad options, as well as their famous frozen Greek yogurt. 
During my visit, I enjoyed a lamb wrap which was DIVINE! The meat was perfectly cooked and the entire wrap had a unique and wonderful pattern of taste. Savory, yet with some sweet notes too. The yogurt was a great way to top everything off. I had the famous Baklava flavor. 

I definitely look forward to stopping by again!
author: Isabel K.

description: Great food! Came here after a suggestion from the company I was interviewing with in San Francisco and the food did not disappoint! The chicken salad was composed of great ingredients which all came together to create a nice taste. The Greek fries were excellent, and my favorite would have to be the tart frozen Greek yogurt topped with baklava crumbles. Had a friend tell me to order this and it lived up to its hype. Would recommend anyone in the SF area to check this out!
author: Hannah J.

description:
Ambiance: Cute little place with long sharing tables and some seating along the side wall. Gets really busy here, so give yourself time to wait in line and find a table. 

Service: You order at the counter then seat yourself. The cashier was friendly.

Food:
We had the free-range chicken, pork shoulder, lamb, and juicy potatoes. Loved them all! The potatoes could have used some more seasoning but they were yummy and there was plenty for the 3 of us.
author: Susan G.

description: This was a great place to stop after exploring the city all afternoon. I loved the veg salad and the fries. Also recommend the frozen Greek yogurt with the baklava topping. It was wonderful. We lucked out with a table opening up right after we ordered but be prepared to wait. Alternatively, there is a park down the street that seemed like an okay spot to eat a to-go order.
author: Kate O.

description: Really solid faster food Greek place! I ordered the lamb salad since I heard it was amazing, which it was!! I little pricey for a salad but the meat was so good that I was okay with it. If you easy there, the do try to kind of rush you out since there is very limited seating and the place is usually packed around lunchtime so just be warned. If it's a nice day, I'd recommend getting it to go and having a seat outside in Hayes instead of in the cramped area.
author: Brandon P.

description:
Finally got to try this place.
The 4 stars is really on the decor, fries, and the frozen yogurt. I wasn't overly impressed with the pork sandwich (in a pita). Thought it was on the dry side and after a few bites, I didn't really want to finish it. 

Best friend got the fries and they were really crispy! May have to get those again!

Definately going back for the yogurt! Super refreshing, sweet but not overly sweet, and very flavorful. Yum!

We got there at 11am on a Saturday and there was a line of 2 people. Around noon, the line was about 15 people plus so the tip is to go earlier.
author: Cicely T.

description: This place actually surprised me. I was expecting plain ol' salads with whatevers meats, but the flavor is actually very nice and the ratio of toppings to greens is right on point. My rotisserie chicken was flavorful and tender, and my friend's pork shoulder sandwich had delicious, tender chunk of pork all throughout. Absolutely flavorful, and more than I expected! This is a great spot if you're craving something fresh and light!
author: Monica L.

description: Recommended by the Timbuk2 store across the road, this turned out to be really good. If this would be near work, I'd be here one day out of two. Recommended: the Leg of Lamb salad.
author: Michael P.

description:
Roasted white sweet potato, garlic yogurt, chopped Kalamata olive, toasted walnut, pickled red onion, toasted pea shoots, Mizithra cheese wrap+Greek fries with olive oil, lemon juice, oregano, Mizithra cheese.

Gwow. Mind blown. Broke my mauf.

My dish was bursting with flavor, tasted so fresh, and was super original. I mean, come on, white sweet potato? Help me, I'm hooked.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Dropped in here a few months ago when they first opened.
Probably wasn't a good idea to eat here smack dab in the middle of a 90 degree heatwave in San Francisco but what the heck... They don't happen often. 
It was HAWT outside and SO HUMID inside the restaurant. I felt so sorry for the girl at the register standing in front of the oven. She was a trooper. 

My friend had the American homestead pork shoulder ($10) w/ minted Greek yogurt, cherry tomato, pickled red onion, cucumber and feta cheese. It was ehhh okaaaay  but a tad on the dry side. 

I had the Superior Farms lamb leg ($12) w/ Harissa spiked yogurt, cucumber, radish, pickled red onions and feta cheese in a sandwich. THIS IS THE MONEY MAKER Y'ALL! That lamb leg was extremely tender and I loved the pickled red onions. I would be even happier if there were MORE pickled red onions. This thing was so damn juicy I was dripping all over the place. 

We also split an order of the Greek Fries ($4) , which you should totally skip and not bother with. They weren't all that special although they were pretty crispy the way I like 'em. If you want yogurt, that's an extra $1. 

We saw bowls and bowls of salad going out TOPPED with fries. A salad with fries!? I must go back for this...

Souvla can be semi pricey for a quick lunch but it's Hayes Valley and they don't exactly have much competition. The place across the street sucks so don't even bring that up.
author: Susy C.

description:
For a quick bite, ok. Chicken-lemon soup great, redzina is decent. I like the chicken salad. 
Lamb, pork are too tough and need to be improved. So are fries!
author: Deniz S.

description:
I'm so obsessed with the "we are happy to serve you" design that I own a ceramic version of the ubiquitous in New York paper coffee cup. Souvla's greek fro yo creations (four in total) are served in these blue & white storied cups, with the olive oil & sea salt-topped one being pretty good. 

I appreciate Souvla's condensed menu. I've been experiencing decision fatigue when it comes to SF's restaurant scene; I'm relieved to have only one option that I'll eat here. Lamb, pork, chicken, & roasted white sweet potato can be made into a sandwich or salad (I chose the white sweet potato salad -- kalamata olives, toasted walnuts, pea shoots, pickled red onion, mizithra cheese, garlic yogurt dressing & added chicken -- which a staff member called "the best thing on the menu!") Rounding out the menu are four sides (Greek fries are super crisp.) 

Despite how uncomfortably warm the small space became as more patrons piled in, I'll return for the same salad & a different  Greek fro yo topping (sour cherry syrup calls my name.)
author: Fancypants X.

description: This is one of my favorite healthy lunch destinations. Delicious, filling salad and salt/olive oil yogurt is to die for. I wish the sidewalk near the restaurant was kept in a better condition making outside eating slightly more enjoyable.
author: Erin B.

description: If you haven't had Souvla's chicken salad, you have. not. lived. So good. Add Greek fries and a side of Granch to get super rowdy, you won't regret.
author: Sheena W.

description:
This place is awesome. We got there during a mad rush for a late lunch but the line moved quickly and the turnover to sit and eat is quick so easily got a seat. I was a bit skeptical because I hate atmospheres where you feel like you are fighting for a seat and made to wait for ever but it seems to be a form of controlled chaos that seemed to work.

Anyhow, the food is awesome. The Chicken salad was one of the better salads I have had...it is a very filling meal. The veggie sando was mediocre, and we should have ordered chicken or pork. The french fries are perfectly thick and crispy. And that greek yougurt with honey...wow seriously delicious. Big fan and can't wait for their new location! Will definitely be back to try some other items on menu.
author: Derek S.

description: Spent 21$ on a beer and sandwich and left hungry. Sandwich was good tho beer was ehhh.
author: Mark O.

description: I met up with an old friend for lunch here on a Sunday afternoon. It was pretty empty when I arrived, but then a line was out the door by the time I left. You order up at the counter and then have your food brought out to your table. I ordered the Lamb Sandwich ($13) and Baklava Greek Ice Cream ($5). First of all, the sandwich had great presentation --very hipster. Unfortunately, it was so tough to eat that I ended up throwing away all of the lamb. It was so hard and flavorless. Somehow, I'm hoping I had a bad piece, but I couldn't even eat it. Instead, I opened up my pita sandwich and just forked out the radish, cucumbers, onions and cheese to eat. I never felt like I wasted my money so much. On the other hand, the greek yogurt is what kind of saved this place. I loved the touch of sour taste in the greek yogurt paired with their various toppings. Although the baklava was something new for me, it was a great option. I tried some of the Olive Oil and Sea Salt flavor from my friend and loved that one too, except I took a spoonful of too much salt. I'd be back for the dessert, but not so much the food.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
The fries were very good! I ate them all which is a rarity. The lamb sandwich was okay, nothing to write home about. I'm a big fan of lamb but the sandwich could have used more flavor.

I liked the casual ambiance and would go back but get a my meal on a salad instead. The lamb was cubed and fell out of my sandwich and on my dress. I'm also a clutz!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
I've been to Souvla a couple times. The first time was for a mid-day meeting with colleagues. At my initial visit, it wasn't very busy since it was around 4 in the afternoon. We were able to grab a couple seats to enjoy their frozen Greek yogurt which was creamy, rich, and slightly tart. I had one with sour cherry syrup and my colleagues had the more popular one with baklava crumbs. I was impressed and vowed to return for an actual meal.

Last night, I went in for dinner with two friends around 7:30 PM. Fearing this was prime dinner hour on a Friday and that there would be hoards of eager San Francisco yuppies, we were prepared for the worst. Thankfully, the line wasn't too bad and we were able to find seating thanks to a family of three that was on their way out. (Seating is first come, first serve.) Every seat was taken and just like the city itself, all space is valuable real estate in a small space like Souvla! 

So how does Souvla work? You take a quick look at the paper menu at the door, and if you're like me you let your happy hour buzz dictate your ordering. That said, with gentle prodding from my oh-so-convincing buddy, I succumbed to wine temptation by ordering a pretty pricy glass of sparkling Greek wine. It was solid, but for a glass that rang up $12, I was hoping for more memorable vino. It was bright with notes of citrus (I'm being partly serious and partly facetious since I don't have the most sophisticated wine connoisseur palate.), but again, I didn't particularly feel that was a good value. Speaking of things not being of good value: the lamb sandwich ($13). Now, I know we live in San Francisco and with Hayes Valley being one of the hubs of bourgeois taste, I still have sticker shock for food that would otherwise be several bucks less elsewhere. The lamb sandwich comprised of chunks of spit-fired lamb leg, harissa-infused yogurt, red onion, cucumber, radish, and feta cheese tucked inside pita. The lamb was prepared well though it could've used more seasoning and wasn't as tender as you'd expect for its cooking method. The accompanying veggies and especially the feta cheese were nicely toothsome. However, I remember the sandwich served at room temperature which was disappointing when I was hoping for some hot meat in a warm pita to go with the chilled sparkling wine. 

The dining room is rather loud so expect to talk very audibly... or go right ahead and do a little shouting if necessary because it's a packed house if last night is like every other night. Again, seating is tricky here. We were eating for about 20ish minutes and 15 of those minutes, there were people literally standing next to our table peering over to see how fast we could eat and how quickly we could drink -- which made eating, at times, a bit stressful. When you can feel the weight of multiple eyes on your table, one cannot help but feel pressured. 

In all, Souvla serves up terrific frozen Greek yogurt but, for me, dinner and the ambiance were middle-of-the-road at best. Thankfully, with wonderful company and lovely friends with you, you're more forgiving of these things as you dine. Souvla is, in the words of Yelp, a solid "3-star, A-OK" joint: good, but not enticing enough for me to return.
author: James Z.

description:
How did I not know about this place until 2016?!? Souvla is one of my favorite new restaurants, and it's partly because of their greek yogurt with baklava crumbles and syrup. The yogurt is the perfect amount of tartness and baklava is just plain delicious so this combination made my tastebuds happy!

My first time going was a Friday night, and it was obviously pretty busy but my friend and I were able to get seats at the bar. Is it even a bar or just a serving station? Either way we got to see glistening meat rotate and cook only 5 feet away from us, which only made me even hungrier! I got the lamb wrap, and it was very tender and juicy. After eating the yogurt first, I couldn't finish my lamb so I had half to take home, and it still tastes good the next day! 

I was creeping a bit and seeing what other people got, and I have to say the salads at Souvla actually looked pretty good too. Definitely come here if you're in Hayes Valley, but try to come with just 1-2 friends or you'll have a hard time getting seats!
author: Grace C.

description: Wow - this place really nails it! The menu is simple (essentially chicken pork or lamb salads or sandwiches, along with fries and frozen yogurt for dessert) but they have their flavors absolutely dialed then. When dining in and ordering from the counter, food comes within mere minutes. And I can't even count how many times I have ordered delivery from this place--I have yet to get tired of their salads. The space can be a bit noisy, and it's not really the type of environment that invites you to linger over your meal, but it can't be beat for a quick meal or carry out.
author: Wally S.

description:
Pros: fast service, friendly people working there, tasty fairly healthy food. 

Cons: small space, limited menu - especially if you're vegetarian  

My wife had the salad with pork and enjoyed it. I didn't feel like the only vegetarian entree they had - grilled sweet potatoes and some other stuff as a sandwich. I opted for a small side salad and fries. They were both good though I'm probably not the only person who will be glad to see the fad of kale in salads pass. There was regular lettuce too but lots of chopped Dino kale. And I adore it cooked - probably have it twice/week. A guy working there popped by a tiny portion of their yogurt ranch sauce for the fries saying it was left over and he didn't want to waste it. It usually costs $1 extra. It was good, especially as a freebie. 

My favorite part of the meal was the frozen Greek yogurt. The yogurt itself was rich and a bit tart. Very delicious. We got one with olive oil and a little too much salt and another with honey. The olive oil and salt was amazing with the yogurt but it was over salted. The honey tasted good but was hard to eat when the honey got cold.
author: Marco M.

description:
I'm going to give this joint a generous 3 stars.  We came here on a friend's glowing recommendation, and were pretty disappointed.

For starters, I'm not a fan of the wait-in-line-and-maybe-you'll-get-a-table-by-the-time-your-food-arrives concept.  But I'm willing to overlook that - that's how they chose to set up shop, and I willingly partook.

We waited in the long line, then jockeyed for and finally got a table.  Yay!  The food arrived not too long thereafter.  Between the four of us, we got two different wraps and two different salads.  I thought my chicken salad was pretty good - the veggies were fresh, and the chicken was tasty.  My three companions weren't quite as thrilled with their food (lamb wrap, chicken wrap, lamb salad).  The lamb in particular lacked the flavor that we were expecting.

The saddest part was the wine selection (all Greek wines, I believe).  When I visited Greece a few years ago, I was consistently unimpressed with the local wine, but I assumed I just didn't know what to order.  At Souvla, we tried two of the wines on the menu.  Both were incredibly sweet, even though we'd asked for the least sweet options, and just not good.  The wine also wasn't very cold (in fact, the metal cup that the wine came in was colder than the wine itself).  We actually left most of the wine on the table, which *never* happens.

Overall, a disappointing experience.
author: Connie S.

description:
Checked this place the other weekend for a nice casual lunch date with a girlfriend. 

We got the lamb and chicken salad over the pita wrap in effort to save some calories. My friend preferred the chicken over the lamb because she found it was a bit more tender and juicy. I agreed and felt the lamb was a bit dry but may be because the meat isn't served as warm,
causing the muscles and such to tighten. 

Again due to the poor timing with the diet I'm on, we passed on the frozen Greek yogurt but when I come back I will totally get that bad boy and even opt for the pita. (They looked gigantic btw!)
author: Lauren Y.

description:
met with a friend i hadnt seen in quite some time at this place, so i guess souvla will always hold a bit of a warmer place in my heart :')

hoo-whee this place is poppin. and for reason too. i would love to spend my evening staring at the spits of chicken and lamb slow-roasting in the coaxing, relaxing heat, in such a warm and charming restaurant painted with beautiful grecco white and blues. the fact that they also have alcohol definitely makes it a place for lovely ambience.

to the food! doesn't take too long to prepare a sandwich or a salad, thankfully, despite the long wait ahead. that's a definite plus. 

i ordered the chicken salad which, by name, seems so incredibly plain. but by golly having those slices of orange atop the wonderful mizithra cheese? quite good. they dress a bit heavily, but the "granch" was pretty tasty! i was disappointed by the chicken tho. dry, no permeating taste. i wonder if they brined or marinated the chicken at all before roasting them. if so, none of that imparted on the chicken, unfortunately.

but O K A Y that greek yogurt is from the shining fields of elysium themselves. a huge serving in that all-too-familiar, always-so-endearing anthora cup. and gee whiz the baklava crumble? bury me in it. i am happy.

im so sad i didnt get to try more of the toppings for the greek yogurt. geez id wait on line for just that greek yogurt alone. i'll miss u souvla.
author: Angie K.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city for a quick yummy lunch or dinner 
(they recently open some new locations, too!)

- Always go LAMB, or go home. JK, but it really is the best.
- Good in salad, great in a (soft, perfect) pita. 

Haven't tried their frozen yogurt but saw some chick get it with baklava and it looked amazing.
author: Rachel T.

description:
While visiting the city we stayed in the Hayes Valley neighborhood. This shop was continuously busy, always a good sign. We ordered the veggie sandwich, the veggie salad and the potatoes.
Cost is reasonable, portions are good, especially the salad, and service is fast. We will return here in the future. FYI, the salad contains lots of kale, and the side of potatoes is quite rich!
author: Jules M.

description: If I could give this place 6 or 7 stars, I totally would!!! I'm from Chicago so we have our fair share of Greek/Mediterranean places too but OMG! This place jumped straight to my number 1 spot! So I had the Greek chicken sandwich with their Greek fries. The sandwich was better than anything I've had here; the chicken was cooked perfectly and their "granch" dressing is out of this world. It's make for an amazing dipping sauce for your fries! Make sure to get your own cause you're not going to want to share as far as I'm concerned. This place will be on my "must go to" list anytime I'm in San Francisco. I can't even imagine what some of the other items on their menu taste like!!!
author: Mark S.

description: I was visiting my friend in Hayes Valley and heard from a few people that this place was "amazing". I went with my girlfriend and we shared the pork salad and the lamb wrap. Wasn't very impressed with either- was actually very disappointed. The wrap was super greasy and I felt sick after eating it. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE
author: Nathan R.

description:
The Greek yogurt is amazing! Had the baklava with honey and salt (because I like my sweets salted) and the flavored blend so well! My sister usually gets olive oil and salt, which actually contrasts great with the sweet tart yogurt that you don't even need a sweetener. 
We always get their veg salad which is also really good with huge chunks of sweet potato contrasting with the salty olives for a satisfying meal. Its such a signature taste that after I visited for the first time I realized I had tried their salad before from my sister's leftovers. It was the aha moment where I finally reunited with that salad. Great service too! The man at the cashier taking orders and preparing the yogurt is so friendly and understanding! Looking forward to trying their other dishes. But definitely the yogurt!
author: Alicia C.

description:
Great casual counter lunch/dinner spot. I love the clean,  modern, chic decor with a large communal table but it can certainly get claustrophobic. The word has gotten out about this place and its safe to say there is always a line and a fight for the first come first serve seating. This bit, and the noise, makes for the experience to be a little less pleasant.
